text: when Hong Kong returned to china in 1997
beijing promised that it would respect
its way of life and that meant the right
to protest along with other freedoms
they also promised that by 2017 Hong
Kong would get direct elections for its
leadership and the trouble is that three
weeks ago Beijing and Lance the rules
for those elections and they don't like
them there's going to be a committee
which will produce just two or three
candidates and they fear that means only
the candidates Beijing likes will get
through so what do they hope this
protest will achieve we are here to
fight for our democracy and to ask the
government to give the democracy day
that they promised I want my voice to be
heard I want voices of people who hold
the same opinion as I do to be heard and
that is that we want the true democracy
we want genuine universal suffrage for
Hong Kong and do you think this protest
will change Beijing's mind i'm not sure
but i mean i've done that we have to do
something to fight boys at least we do
something for us campaigners say this
student strike is just a beginning that
there's a wider campaign of civil
disobedience coming but beijing says
it's not listening they say
western-style democracy would be bad for
Hong Kong create chaos and that these
protests being stirred up by foreign
governments were determined not just to
undermine the stability prosperity of
Hong Kong but who are trying to subvert
China through this
